Award.AwardTitle: AF: Small: Geometry-aware Integral Equation Solvers for High-fidelity Electromagnetic Modeling and Simulation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
For the design of antennas to aircraft, it is important to simulate the electromagnetic behavior of objects with many parts or complex geometry. This project investigates geometry-aware, high-performance integral equation (IE) solvers: decomposing the geometry and creating algorithms that fit new mathematics to the geometry. This research enables integrated design and simulation in engineering applications via reconfigurable modeling and reusable simulation: by generating analysis-suitable models per-component and independently analyzing individual components, one can hope to automatically assemble components to simulate a virtual prototype of an entire product. This will overcome key challenges in simulation-based engineering and science (SBES), resulting in high-fidelity simulation software that can advance computer-aided design and engineering (CAD/CAE).

This proposal aims to investigate high-resolution and high-performance IE solvers for time-harmonic Maxwell Equations, whose simulation capability and modeling fidelity scale with the exponential growth in computing power. This objective will be attained through three major research efforts:
1.) investigate a geometry-adaptive multi-resolution discontinuous Galerkin (DG) boundary element method, which permits the use of non-conformal surface discretizations, allows mixing different types of elements, and facilitates the mesh generation task for high-definition objects.
2.) investigate a well-conditioned multi-trace IE formulation for complex composite objects to resolve the intricacies of materials in composite structures.
3.) develop a geometry-aware domain decomposition (DD) method to conquer the geometric complexity of physical domains.

The work will impact design of advanced antennas, optical integrated circuits, nanomaterials and other engineering applications.
The capability of the developed algorithms will be illustrated in applications ranging from high-definition jet aircraft to radar stealth objects to nanoparticles and plasmonic nanoantennas. A modular software library will implement the algorithms developed, with detailed documentation to allow wide reuse. On the educational side, this project will train students (from undergraduates to graduates) in computational mathematics, electromagnetics, microwave engineering and computer-aided engineering, and will broaden participation via UNM undergraduate research and education programs (PROFOUND, PREP) and minority outreach programs (New Mexico AMP and HESO). This will foster greater awareness and interest in computational science and engineering, and reinforce student preparation to face future challenges.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past decades, the computer simulation of electromagnetic (EM) phenomena has emerged as a powerful and indispensable tool in both the design and analysis stages of many engineering endeavors. These simulations are enabled by fast and rigorous numerical solutions of Maxwell's Equations as well as rapid advances in high-performance computing (HPC) systems. Today, the field of electromagnetic computation is in a great transition. The growing sophistication in real-world EM applications and the increasing demand on the highest fidelity analysis have driven the need for the next generation mathematics and algorithms. Moreover, the fast evolving computing environment calls for high-performance software, which makes best use of emerging exascale computing resources.  

To support current and future simulation-driven scientific discoveries, the proposed research addresses the following major difficulties in high-fidelity EM modeling and simulation: the geometrical complexity of the underlying structures, the computational complexity for extremely large multi-scale computations, and the intricacies of composite EM materials.

The main results of the project are summarized as follows:

Novelty and technical ingredients:

1. The geometry-aware hybrid finite element-boundary integral equation (FE-BI) method with quasi-linear computational complexity;

2. A well-conditioned multi-trace IE formulation for complex composite objects, which leads to the quasi-optimal convergence in iterative solutions that is provably scalable for multi-scale composite objects;

3. A geometry-aware hybrid boundary integral equation-impedance boundary condition (IE-IBC) method for perfect electric conducting objects coated with multilayer thin materials;

4. A parallel and adaptive h-refinement discontinuous Galerkin boundary element method, which adaptively chooses the resolution of approximation for a desired level of accuracy in the analysis of multi-scale structures;

5. Scalable, hierarchical, and parallel IE solvers with superior parallel efficiency and scalability on massively parallel platforms.

Mission-critical EM applications:

1. In-situ antenna characterization and co-site interference analysis on high-definition military and commercial aircrafts;

2. Protective and aerodynamic radome covers with embedded frequency selective surface modeling for large-scale platforms;

3. Simulation-driven analysis and design of advanced Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) systems;

4. Wireless channel modeling in complex, real-world environments. It is critical for the analysis, design, and application of current and future mobile and wireless communication systems.

Simulation-based engineering and science (SBE&S) is emerging as the critical new asset for scientific discovery and innovation. The on-going work in this research is expected to bring forward a new generation of EM software that will revolutionize high-fidelity EM simulation, prediction, design and analysis. As a result, it will dramatically improve our ability to develop and predict the behavior of modern complex EM systems, while maintaining a high level of confidence on the system behavior and EM vulnerability. The capability and benefits of the resulting algorithms and software are exploited and illustrated through challenging extreme-scale EM computations.
